data.title: ExtendedMove changes
data.body:
- Support for three positions and rotations.
- Increased the number of bits used to network rotations.
- New Euler based rotation support, in addition to the existing
  quaternion support.

data.title: Fix platforms that don't support PVI_NumAdapters
data.body:
Not all platforms currently support the PVI_NumAdapters query from
PlatformVideoInfo.  This fix puts in the assumption that there is always
1 adapter if the PVI_NumAdapaters query returns false.  This was the
behaviour prior to PVI_NumAdapters being put in place.

data.title: Clean up the cheetah's onLoad() TSShapeConstructor script
data.body: This prevents some console spam due to erroneous node removal requests.

data.title: GFX now handles non-default adapters
data.body:
The GFX (DirectX) pipeline did not respect the choice of adapter and always went for the default one.  Normally this isn't an issue unless you wish to target a particular adapter and display device combination.  This has been corrected.

The GFX initialize functions now attempt to find the best adapter that matches a given display device (i.e. monitor) if one has been passed in.  To aid with choosing a display device some new monitor enumeration methods have been added to the platform window manager.  These methods have been exposed to the Canvas.

The new $pref::Video::displayOutputDevice console variable is used to set the display device to target.  You set this prior to creating the Canvas, just like you would with $pref::Video::displayDevice.

data.title: zero() method added to all point classes
data.body:
Only some of the mPointX classes had the zero() method implemented.
This commit adds the method to all point classes.

data.title: Fix texture and object console paths
data.body:
- Be sure to delete all prefs.cs files following this change.
- Changes the console types of the missing, unavailable and warning
  texture paths.  The old type was causing string corruption when saving
  preferences.
- Changes the console type of the TSShapeConstructor collision shapes.
  The old type was causing string corruption when saving preferences.
- Changed missing texture reference in ProcessedMaterial from String to
  const char*.

data.title: Add buttons to the MainMenu to access the Editors.
Add missing terrain related materials.
data.body: This prevents the "cannot find material X" messages in the console.  These psuedo materials are what enables footstep sounds and footpuffs on terrain materials.

data.title: Add and remove relevant file execs for the new weapon fx usage
data.body: Missed this in previous change @ pull request #312

data.title: Cleanup of weapon fx and assets.
data.body:
This reduces asset duplication by grouping assets used by multiple weapons in one location: shared.
This simplifies fx related datablock duplication that was spread across multiple files.  We now have rocketfx.cs and grenadefx.cs for the relevant effects.
This cleanup also fixes some minor particle fx console warnings/errors.
Fixed missing material for Cheetah Turret.

data.title: GUI - Crash occurs if you attempt to use a bitmap that is not in the project folder.
data.body:
If you attempt to set a gui bitmap to an image that is not within the projects folder structure, the editor will crash.

Expected: No crash.

Steps to reproduce:
1. open the GUI editor for a project.
2. Select StartupGui.
3. Select the StartupLogo GuiBitmapButtonCtrl.
4. In the bitmap field, click the "..." button to browse for an image.
5. Navigate to an alternate directory like D:/images.
6. Select an image to use in that directory.
7. Observe the application has stopped working error message.

Note: This was found in the development branch from 4/5/2013.

data.title: Remove Interior Object format (DIF)
Crash when loading DDS with uncommon mipmap dimensions
data.body: A crash is occuring in GFXD3D9TextureManager::_loadTexture(GFXTextureObject *aTexture, DDSFile *dds) when loading a DDS file with irregular dimensions of mipmap levels in it: 1048, 524, 262, etc. Line 618 - dMemcpy( dstBytes, srcBytes, srcPitch );

data.title: VectorResize / realloc_r memory leak with forests
data.body:
Build: T3D MIT 2.0
Platform: Windows 7 64 bit 4Gb ram 
Target: Fly Cam

Issues: 
My problem
I was getting crashes every 4 minutes with my stock t3d mit 2.0 client when trying to work on my map and i couldn't understand it as i wasn't getting anything in the console.log and i'm not a c++ developer or anything to really understand how to track it down in the engine

The Cause
With some help with the guys in maxgaming IRC channel they helped me compile a debug mode client and track down the cause of the crash

To get the crash to happen I would fly around the map until the crash occured and it would return an error VectorResize - Allocation Failed - usually this took about 4 minutes or so

Looking at the call stack when this occured it appeared that the VectorResize was being called by the ForestCell:buildBatches() method so it was clickly apparent this was being caused by the forest - i use the conifer forest pack by the way

Xifos in the IRC channel asked me to add some breakpoints to see if VectorResize was doing an allocate or a reallocate - we tested this and it was using Realloc_r. He then asked me to step through each breakpoint as I moved around my map looking at new areas of the forest and watch my memory usage - it seemed to rise 200mb from 1.6gb to 1.83gb and then at that point it would crash

He suggested this might be a memory leak but resolving it was beyond him so he suggested I post here - so here you go!

For now I have scrapped my map and creating a much smaller one that is using around 1.2gb ram on idle and so far I have had 0 crashes over the last 3 hours

Steps to Repeat:
1. Load up Torque 2.0 MIT
2. Load a map that uses around 1.6gb ram with a large forest and all your assets
3. Fly around the map and watch the memory usage increase until the client crashes

data.title: Fix for issue #282
data.body: Material selector now renders preview thumbnails.

data.title: Removing the Armor script class.
data.body: Using PlayerData as the generic namespace.  This is more inline with other default datablock methods.

data.title: Remove the Armor script class.
data.body: Use PlayerData for generic datablock namespace methods.

data.title: Relocate default road & path assets.
Dev Branch - Material Browser thumbnails do not render correctly.
data.body:
In the material browser, all the thumbnails are white instead of the correct material thumbnail.

Expected: Material thumbnails are displayed correctly.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the world editor for a project.
2. Open the material editor.
3. Click the folder to open an existing material.
4. Observe all material thumbnails are white.

Note: If you cycle through the pages of materials, a crash occurs.

data.title: Relocate water related assets.
data.body: Also remove duplication, favoring DDS over other formats.

data.title: Dev Branch - Attempting to create collision for cube object causes a crash.
data.body:
In the shape editor, if you attempt to change the collision fit type, a crash occurs while attempting to generate collision.

Expected: Collision is generated correctly.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a project from the full template.
2. Open the world editor.
3. Open the shape editor.
4. Open the Cube object from the library.
5. Open the Collision Tab.
6. Change the Fit type box sphere or capsule.
7. Observe Crash.
